Line 327: Line 327:
==Domestic responses==
==Domestic responses==
{{main|Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian protests}}
{{main|Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian protests}}
â
+
[[Image:MubarakBurnsEgypt.jpg |thumb|"Nero burned Rome; Mubarak is burning Egypt"]]
On 29 January, Mubarak indicated he would be changing the government because despite a "point of no return" being crossed, national stability and [[law and order (politics)|law and order]] must prevail, that he had requested the government, formed only months ago, to step down, and that a new government would be formed.<ref>Breaking News. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. 29 November 1:30 Egypt time</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41318467/|title=Protesters Return to Cairo's Main Square – Egyptian President Fires His Cabinet But Refuses To Step Down|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> He then appointed [[Omar Suleiman]], head of Egyptian Intelligence, as vice president and [[Ahmed Shafik]] as prime minister.<ref>{{cite news|last=Slackman|first=Michael|title=Choice of Suleiman Likely to Please the Military, Not the Crowds|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/30/world/middleeast/30suleiman.html?src=twrhp|accessdate=3 February 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=29 January 2011}}</ref> On 1 February, he spoke again saying he would stay in office until [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|the next election in September 2011]] and then leave without standing as a candidate. He also promised to make political reforms.
On 29 January, Mubarak indicated he would be changing the government because despite a "point of no return" being crossed, national stability and [[law and order (politics)|law and order]] must prevail, that he had requested the government, formed only months ago, to step down, and that a new government would be formed.<ref>Breaking News. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. 29 November 1:30 Egypt time</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41318467/|title=Protesters Return to Cairo's Main Square – Egyptian President Fires His Cabinet But Refuses To Step Down|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> He then appointed [[Omar Suleiman]], head of Egyptian Intelligence, as vice president and [[Ahmed Shafik]] as prime minister.<ref>{{cite news|last=Slackman|first=Michael|title=Choice of Suleiman Likely to Please the Military, Not the Crowds|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/30/world/middleeast/30suleiman.html?src=twrhp|accessdate=3 February 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=29 January 2011}}</ref> On 1 February, he spoke again saying he would stay in office until [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|the next election in September 2011]] and then leave without standing as a candidate. He also promised to make political reforms.
Line 337: Line 337:
Egyptian and foreign equity and commodity markets also reacted negatively to the increasing instability.
Egyptian and foreign equity and commodity markets also reacted negatively to the increasing instability.
â   â
===Protester demands===
  â
[[Image:MubarakBurnsEgypt.jpg |thumb|"Nero burned Rome; Mubarak is burning Egypt"]]
  â
Opposition and civil society activists have called for changes to a number of legal and constitutional provisions which affect elections. Specifically they call for:
  â
*Amendment of Article 76 of the Constitution to make it easier for party and independent candidates to get on the presidential ballot.
  â
*Amendment of Article 77 to establish term limits for the presidency, which were removed from the Constitution in 1981.
  â
*Amendment of Article 88 to restore full judicial supervision of elections. This would help tame election fraud and vote rigging, which are common in Egyptian elections.
  â
*Amendment of Law 177 of 2005 in order to facilitate the formation of new political parties.
  â
*Amendment of Article 179: Amendments in 2007 to Article 179 included an "anti-terrorism" measure, which allows for arbitrary arrest, searches and wiretapping without warrant, and transfer of any civilian court case of the presidentâs choosing to military tribunals. Unlike the Emercency law, it is a permanent measure and not a temporary measure requiring parlimentary approval.
  â   â
In the Spring 2010, Mohamed Elbaradei began circulating a petition in the runup to the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010]] calling for 7 specific reforms:
  â
#End the state of emergency.
  â
#Ensure full judicial supervision of elections.
  â
#Provide for domestic and international monitoring of elections.
  â
#Ensure that all candidates have sufficient access to the media, particularly during the presidential election campaign.
  â
#Allow Egyptians abroad to vote through embassies and consulates.
  â
#Work toward a political system built on democracy and social justice.
  â
#Provide the right to nomination for political office without obstacles, in accordance with Egyptâs obligations under the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights; limit the president to two terms.
  â
#Allow voting by national identification card. These measures will require amending articles 76, 77, and 88 of the Constitution as soon as possible.<ref name="egyptelections">{{cite web|first=Matthew|url=http://egyptelections.carnegieendowment.org/2010/09/01/constitutional-and-legal-framework|title=Constitutional and Legal Framework|work=[[Carnegie Endowment]] |location=Washington, D.C.|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
===National Dialogue===
  â
Vice President Omar Suleiman was ordered by Mubarak to conduct negotiations with opposition groups. Among the major ideas circulated was a compromise in which Suleiman would be delegated all of Mubarak's authorities for an interim period and Mubarak would stay on as an [[emeritus|honourary]] president for that period.<ref>[http://www.hindustantimes.com/Suleiman-mulling-figurehead-role-for-Mubarak/Article1-658783.aspx 'Suleiman mulling figurehead role for Mubarak'], hindustantimes, February 05, 2011</ref>
